Heading: Alberto Vaccari
Note: Alberto Vaccari – Pontificio Istituto Biblico

Heading: Amplified
Note: A translation based on the American Standard Version and showing multiple options for the translation of ancient text. Published in full in 1965. Sponsored by the Lockman Foundation

Heading: Antonio Martini
Note: Most popular Catholic Bible translation in Italian prior to the CEI translation in 1971

Heading: American Standard
Note: A 1901 translation using verbal equivalence techniques with the purpose of Americanizing the REV

Heading: Common English Bible
Note: 2011 contemporary English translation of the Bible sponsored by the US-based Christian Resources Development Corporation. The translation includes Old Testament, Apocrypha and New Testament, and is aimed to be accessible to most English readers (minimum 7th grade reading age)

Heading: Conferenza Episcopale Italiana
Note: Italian Episcopal Conference 1971 translation suitable for Italian Catholic liturgy. (Includes minor 1974 revision)

Heading: Conferenza Episcopale Italiana 2008
Note: New translation of the C.E.I. first published in 2008 – the version most widely used by the Italian Catholic Church

Heading: Contemporary English
Note: A translation completed in 1995 and sponsored by the American Bible Society under the leadership of Barclay Newman

Heading: Concordata
Note: 1968 Interfaith version promoted by the Italian Bible Society. Has a Catholic ‘imprimateur’, but its ecumenical approach has Jewish, Protestant and Christian Orthodox approval

Heading: Diodati
Note: Version based on original documents, edited by Giovanni Diodati in 1607, revised by Diodati in 1641 and again in 1894. It is the reference version for many Italian Protestants

Heading: Nuova Diodati
Note: Revision of the Diodati Bible dating to the 1990s, aiming at highest fidelity to original ancient Greek (New Testament) and Hebrew (Old Testament) texts

Heading: Douay-Rheims
Note: An early (1580-1609) English translation from the Latin Vulgate designed for Catholics and performed by George Martin

Heading: Einheitsübersetzung
Note: A German translation of the Bible for use in Roman Catholic churches

Heading: English Standard
Note: An update of the Revised Standard Version that makes ‘modest’ use of gender-free terminology

Heading: Biblia (1776)
Note: Finnish Bible translation

Heading: Raamattu (1933/1938)
Note: Finnish Bible translation

Heading: Raamattu kansalle
Note: Finnish Bible translation

Heading: Raamattu (1992)
Note: Finnish Bible translation

Heading: God’s Word
Note: A 1995 translation by the World Bible Publishing Company using the English language in a manner to communicate to the late 20th century American

Heading: Geneva
Note: An early (1560) English version of the Bible translated by William Whittingham with strong Protestant leanings

Heading: Good News
Note: A translation sponsored by the American Bible Society. The New Testament was first published (as ‘Today’s English Version’ TEV) in 1966. The Old Testament was completed in 1976, and the whole was published as the ‘Good News Bible’

Heading: Galbiati, Penna, Rossano – UTET
Note: Version edited by E. Galbiati, A. Penna and P. Rossano, and published by UTET. This version, based on original texts, is rich in notes and has been used as the basis for CEI translation

Heading: Original Greek
Note: New Testament text in an original Greek version

Heading: Garofano, Rinaldi – Marietti
Note: Richly annotated 1963 Version edited by S. Garofano and S. Rinaldi, and published by Marietti

Heading: Original Hebrew
Note: Old Testament text in an original Hebrew version

Heading: Holman Christian Standard
Note: Published by Broadman and Holman this translation rejects all forms of gender-neutral wording and is written with strong influences from the Southern Baptist perspective of biblical scholarship

Heading: International Children’s
Note: A translation completed in 1986 targeting readability at the US third grade level

Heading: Traduzione Interconfessionale in Lingua Corrente
Note: Interconfessional translation resulting from 1985 effort by Catholic and Protestant scholars, aimed at delivering an easy-to-understand message

Heading: Jerusalem
Note: A translation designed for English speaking Catholics based on the original languages. It is based on French as well as ancient texts and was first published in 1966

Heading: King James
Note: A translation commissioned by King James I of England and first published in 1611

Heading: 21st Century King James
Note: A verbal translation led by William Prindele. Published in 1994, it was designed to modernize the language of the King James Version based on Webster’s New International Dictionary, 2nd edition, unabridged

Heading: Living Bible
Note: A paraphrase translation led by Kenneth N Taylor and first published in 1972

Heading: Luzzi
Note: 1924 translation by Giovanni Luzzi, Professor at the Waldensian Faculty of Theology in Rome, who revised the 17th Century Diodati version

Heading: Message Bible
Note: A paraphrase translation of the New Testament by Eugene Peterson first published in 1993

Heading: New American
Note: A translation aimed at Catholic readers first published in its entirety in 1970. A revised New Testament was issued in 1986 as the 2nd Edition. The 3rd Edtion was published in 1991 with a revision to Psalms. The 4th Edition (also known as the New American Bible Revised Edition) was published in 2011, incorporating revisions to the Old Testament

Heading: New American Standard
Note: A translation commissioned by the Lockman Foundation. The New Testament was published in 1960 followed by the entire Bible in 1971

Heading: New American Standard, Updated
Note: A 1995 translation using more modern language than the NASB

Heading: Bibelen 1895
Note: Norwegian Bible translation

Heading: Bibelen 1930
Note: Norwegian Bible translation

Heading: Bibelen 1938
Note: Norwegian Bible translation

Heading: Bibelen 1978-85
Note: Norwegian Bible translation

Heading: Bibelen 1978
Note: Norwegian Bible translation

Heading: Bibelen 1985
Note: Norwegian Bible translation

Heading: Bibelen 1988
Note: Norwegian Bible translation

Heading: Bibelen 1978-85/rev. 2005
Note: Norwegian Bible translation

Heading: Bibelen 2011
Note: Norwegian Bible translation

Heading: New Century
Note: A translation inspired by the International Children’s version. First published by World Publishing in 1991

Heading: New English
Note: A translation first issued in 1961 (New Testament) and 1970 (complete Bible) as a result of a proposal at the 1946 General Assembly of the Church of Scotland

Heading: Bibelen Guds ord
Note: Norwegian Bible translation

Heading: New International
Note: A translation underwritten by Biblica (formerly the International Bible Society, and previously the New York Bible Society). The New Testament was published in 1973 followed by the entire Bible in 1978. The NIV text was revised in 1984 and again in 2011

Heading: New International Reader’s
Note: A 1996 translation designed for people with limited literacy in English and based on the NIV

Heading: New Jerusalem
Note: A revision of the Jerusalem Bible. First published in 1986

Heading: New King James
Note: A version issued by Thomas Nelson Publishers in 1982-83 designed to update the language of the King James Version while maintaining the phrasing and rhythm and using the same sources as its predecessor

Heading: Bibelen, nynorsk
Note: Norwegian ‘nynorsk’ Bible translation

Heading: New Living
Note: A translation sponsored by Tyndale House and first released in 1996. It is considered a revision and updating of the Living Bible

Heading: New Revised Standard
Note: A revision of the Revised Standard based on ancient texts but updating language to American usage of the 1980s

Heading: Nueva Traduccion Vivienta
Note: A Spanish translation from the original Greek and Hebrew, sponsored by Tyndale House

Heading: Novissima Versione della Bibbia
Note: Nuovissima version – a Catholic-oriented translation in modern Italian, edited by a group including Carlo Martini, Gianfranco Ravasi and Ugo Vanni and first published (in 48 volumes, 1967-1980) by Edizioni San Paolo

Heading: Nueva Biblia al Dia
Note: A Spanish translation from the original Greek and Hebrew, sponsored by the International Bible Society/Sociedad Bíblica Internacional

Heading: Nueva Version Internacional
Note: A Spanish translation underwritten by the International Bible Society

Heading: New Testament in Modern English (Phillips)
Note: An idiomatic translation by J B Phillips, first completed in 1966

Heading: Revised English
Note: A 1989 revision of the NEB. A significant effort was made to reduce the British flavor present in the NEB

Heading: Revised Version
Note: The first major revision of the King James Version, the Revised Version incorporates insights from early manuscripts discovered between 1611 and 1870, and corrects readings in the KJV which nineteenth-century scholarship deemed mistaken. The New Testament was published in 1881, the Old Testament in 1885, and the Apocrypha in 1895

Heading: Revised Standard
Note: A translation authorized by the National Council of Churches of Christ in the USA. The New Testament was published in 1946 followed by a complete Protestant canon in 1951

Heading: Reina Valera
Note: A Spanish translation based on the original texts

Heading: Bibel 2000
Note: Swedish Bible translation

Heading: Bibelen, samisk
Note: Norwegian ‘samisk’ Bible translation

Heading: Today’s English
Note: A translation of the New Testament sponsored by the American Bible Society and first published in 1966. It was incorporated into the ‘Good News Bible’ (GNB) in 1976

Heading: Today’s New International
Note: An updating of the New International Version. The New Testament was published in 2002, and the entire Bible in 2005. Superseded by the 2011 NIV update

Heading: Other
Note: Other translations not otherwise noted
